Award.AwardTitle: SCC-CIVIC-PG Track A: Meeting COVID and Household Affordability Challenges through Flex Streets and Dynamic Bicycle Transportation Infrastructure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to merge the need for flexibility affordability, and physical distancing along our streets by developing flexible traffic signal infrastructure. The goal is to use smart and connected communication systems to maximize the throughput of people on bike, scooter, and other micromobility modes and minimize physical proximity (when needed) that happens if a group arrives at a red light in any given cycle. With safe and efficient infrastructure, micromobility has the potential to meet a majority of household trip needs, is more affordable than car ownership allowing households to either reduce expenses or allocate more to address housing needs, and is more inclusive for people aged eight to eighty to access their communities more fully.

This work proposes to expand the nation’s only bicycle and driving simulation lab to create dynamic, immersive environments to test new V2X communication with flexible streets and traffic signals that can help municipalities dynamically and quickly change the use of their public right of way due to changing needs, whether due to pandemics, disasters, or just to respond to overall changing community preferences. The team intends to install a network of traffic signals and test the efficacy of this new smart system on streets in Portland, Oregon, in partnership with community stakeholders. The team includes researchers in urban planning, transportation engineering, and computer science from two universities, a private sector vendor of next generation smart traffic signals, and traffic engineers from the cities of Portland (OR) and Utrecht (Netherlands). The results of this work can help fully integrate micromobility into traffic signal systems, in a scalable way, that also gives information to users in ways that help them optimize their travel. This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program, Track A— Communities and Mobility: Offering Better Mobility Options to Solve the Spatial Mismatch Between Housing Affordability and Jobs—and is a collaboration between NSF and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This planning grant was focused on developing a more extensive proposal with the aim to improve the efficiency of micromobility via nextgen, multi-stakeholder responsive traffic signals to meet societal challenges of climate change, household affordability, and public health. During the project, key stakeholders and project parameters were achieved, including:

1. Identifying a key, equity-based corridor in Portland, Oregon for project implementation and evaluation;

2. Developing a diverse project team across sectors including local government (Portland), a scooter company (Lime), the transit system (TriMet), a traffic signal manufacturer (QFree), and an optical street user sensor maker (Technolution); and

3. Developing a successful core research team that spans three disicplines and two universities, including city planning (Marc Schlossberg, University of Oregon), Computer Science (Stephen Fickas, University of Oregon), and Civil Engineering (David Hurwitz, Oregon State University).

We view housing, employment, and transportation as intermixed. We believe that expanding affordable and efficient transportation options will also expand housing options, which then increases accessible options for employment and broadens the catchment area for non-work household trips. We are also focused on low-carbon and more space-efficient transport that is safe and fast, as well as integrating flexibility into the transportation system to respond to unpredictable, but emergent challenges like the need to support physical distancing during a pandemic.

Our vision has brought us to a critical, yet ubiquitous, stumbling block: cities? use of car-centric Traffic Management Systems (TMS) that systematically disadvantage users of non-car transport. Our vision, therefore, includes changing this fundamental paradigm of our streets by focusing on the prioritization of micromobility options, including bikes (and e-bikes) and scooters. We propose to develop and implement an entirely new type of TMS, called a Micromobility Management System (MMS) that favors these more affordable, equitable, climate-friendly, and space efficient modes of transport, giving users a safe and efficient ride, a greater range of acceptable travel, and more access to a region's jobs, services, and other daily household destinations.

The outcome of this planning grant has us poised to develop, implement, and evaluate such a system within 12 months of a successful Stage 2 award.
